channel.title: The New York Times Trends
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title: Under a law that goes into effect Friday in Maryland, health care workers who are not physicians — including nurses, midwives and physician assistants — will be legally allowed to provide abortions. https://t.co/FtSm3Eebgd

As G7 leaders gather in Germany, fossil fuels are having a wartime resurgence, and the scramble to replace Russian oil and gas is raising concerns that hard-won climate targets will be missed. https://t.co/yJGNAmlm7z
Breaking News: California lawmakers have placed a state constitutional amendment that would explicitly protect abortion rights on the November ballot. https://t.co/h4wGCSHvCc

President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine spoke to G7 leaders by video on Monday. The address was another opportunity for him to demand more advanced weapons from allies as Ukrainian forces come under assault in the country’s east. https://t.co/Nbc6SKmmws

A Russian missile strike hit a shopping center in Ukraine’s central Poltava region on Monday, killing at least 11 people and wounding dozens more, the Ukrainian authorities said, estimating that 1,000 people may have been inside. https://t.co/dtPTKUllsp https://t.co/wPebdPwWFb

Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez is calling for a House investigation into whether two Supreme Court justices who voted to overturn Roe v. Wade should be impeached for lying at their confirmation hearings about their views of the landmark abortion-rights case.https://t.co/AJYgdj4PlL

A coalition of 22 state attorneys general on Monday vowed to defend abortion rights. "If you seek access to abortion and reproductive health care, we’re committed to using the full force of the law to support you," they wrote in a statement. https://t.co/uDJXBH8wDS

Breaking News: Sam Gilliam, a pioneering abstract painter, best known for his lusciously stained Drape paintings, and the first Black artist to represent the U.S. at the Venice Biennale, is dead at 88. https://t.co/fdqgFGwYH2

Abortion has become or will soon become illegal in more than a dozen states whose legislatures had passed so-called trigger laws, allowing for bans shortly after the Supreme Court decision overturning Roe v. Wade on Friday.
Follow live updates: https://t.co/7aJ4FJP5Io https://t.co/Hq5jR2s7ho

After the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade on Friday, several companies have committed to helping their U.S. employees get access to reproductive care they may not be able to obtain in their state. https://t.co/WBDV0FiAgd https://t.co/x03ORJF2k8

Breaking News: A Russian court said the U.S. basketball star Brittney Griner’s trial would start Friday. Griner, who has been detained since February, will remain in custody until the trial ends, her lawyer said. https://t.co/7nzEuZvMBb

Breaking News: A crowded shopping center in central Ukraine was hit by a Russian missile strike, killing at least 10 people and wounding dozens more, authorities said. Ukraine’s president said an estimated 1,000 people had been inside the building. https://t.co/4VmQ2TpMoi

Breaking News: The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol abruptly scheduled a session for Tuesday afternoon to hear “recently obtained evidence” and witness testimony. https://t.co/ucql8gyWGA
Revelers at the annual New York City Pride March on Sunday expressed concern about the future of gay rights after the overturning of Roe v. Wade. https://t.co/jGMe3L6Vup https://t.co/mxqc83Z9og

Abortion is now banned in at least nine states, with trigger bans in several more set to take effect in the coming days. Laws in eight states took effect on Friday after the Supreme Court ruled to overturn Roe v. Wade. https://t.co/qddE0XCDLw https://t.co/W1gKU2MpUu
Russian missiles hit a shopping center in central Ukraine, officials said. As many as 1,000 people may have been inside, but the number of casualties is unknown. https://t.co/2owz2rADPN

Breaking News: The Supreme Court ruled that a high school football coach had a constitutional right to pray at the 50-yard line after his team’s games. The vote was 6 to 3, with the court’s three liberal members in dissent. https://t.co/8n01cJza0e

The public listing of Donald Trump’s social media company took a new blow on Monday when the shell company merging with Trump’s company disclosed in a regulatory filing that a grand jury in New York had issued subpoenas regarding the merger. https://t.co/PUsBXr6Qak

On the first day of their gathering, G7 leaders moved to increase the economic pressure on Russia and announced that they would stop buying its gold. But a missile attack on the Ukrainian capital made clear that Moscow is not backing down. https://t.co/1OfdzxbRTT https://t.co/ZOkq3aTZor

As missiles struck the Ukrainian capital Sunday, sending Kyiv into collective fear, one of its soldiers was laid to rest in an emotional funeral in the suburb of Bortnychi. His mother plunged to her knees and cried out, "I beg you, put me next to him!" https://t.co/SbuFnoehAQ https://t.co/3tLLkoMhok

At least six people were killed and more than a hundred injured at a bullfighting festival in El Espinal, Colombia, when wooden spectator stands collapsed. Among those killed was a 1-year-old child, local media reported. https://t.co/7zljJ7BYVL https://t.co/GaETcZHoQw
A new report shows that having a mortgage is far more expensive than having a lease, a disparity that is helping to cool a red-hot housing market. https://t.co/yyfnEJNqSy

"I grew up in the Jim Crow South," John Grisham said. "A very segregated, racist society was almost in my DNA. It’s a long struggle to overcome that and to look back at the way I was raised and not be resentful toward my parents and other people." https://t.co/anNTz5hDyQ

A Vatican News editorial reiterated the Catholic Church’s defense of "unborn life," but emphasized that this goes beyond abortion. It said truly "being for life" meant addressing maternal mortality rates in the U.S., poverty and "the threat of firearms." https://t.co/w282zER1MF

The end of Roe v. Wade shifted the abortion fight to state legislatures, where gerrymandering has given Republicans an advantage. As abortion becomes illegal in half of the country, democratic self-governance may be nearly out of reach for some voters. https://t.co/tKtMdLB4kD

Across China, the police are buying technology that harnesses troves of data on civilians to predict crimes and protests before they happen. The systems target people deemed suspicious even if they’ve done nothing wrong. https://t.co/zQ5l93g63U

A grocery store worker on Staten Island was arrested Sunday after hitting Rudy Giuliani while the former mayor campaigned for his son, a GOP candidate for governor. Giuliani said in an interview that the man said, "You're going to kill women." https://t.co/YjI3ahIuR3

Recent studies in humans and mice have shown that late nights and early mornings may cause long lasting damage to your brain and increase the risk of neurodegenerative disorders like Alzheimer’s disease. https://t.co/nNeLOiky36

Organizers of Sunday's Pride March in New York City placed Planned Parenthood at the head of the event after the Supreme Court decision ending Roe v. Wade. For all of the joyous celebrations, the court's ruling cast an undeniable shadow. https://t.co/2d6dRLAQc4 https://t.co/QAkdO3QK6i

In light of the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade, advocates from all sides of the issue have called for men to be part of the conversation. The New York Times heard from hundreds who wanted to share their stories. https://t.co/pOhuNGjLTk https://t.co/qBZiV0DMsp

"Reproductive freedom is a right under Minnesota law."
Gov. Tim Walz signed an executive order declaring state agencies won't cooperate in the investigation, arrest or surrender of anyone charged by another state for coming there for an abortion. https://t.co/LEU4QngXyd

Across China, the police are buying technology that harnesses troves of data on civilians to predict crimes and protests before they happen.
The systems target people deemed suspicious, even if they’ve done nothing wrong. Here's what to know. https://t.co/IcudtGLAbG

In Opinion
"How do we ask young people just starting out, or older people who have seen so much progress reversed, to care about a country that seems so determined to care so little for them?" asks Pamela Paul. https://t.co/zhQ5c9fwAo

The Vatican released thousands of letters from Jewish people begging for help during the Holocaust to "allow the descendants of those who asked for help to find traces of their loved ones from any part of the world," its foreign minister said. https://t.co/hQjVQbo2RO
Breaking news: The U.S. and the rest of the G7 nations will ban imports of gold from Russia, aiming to undercut a key source of revenue amid its war in Ukraine. https://t.co/YxSVnpiZaP

Two people were killed and at least 19 injured early Saturday morning in downtown Oslo when a gunman opened fire outside two nightclubs and a diner, the police and Norway’s state broadcaster said. https://t.co/fmcbxg4f5v

Companies that have said they would cover travel expenses for employees who need abortions include Starbucks, Tesla, Yelp, Airbnb, Netflix, Patagonia, DoorDash, JPMorgan Chase, Levi Strauss & Co. and Reddit. https://t.co/KDbGkHEauN
For Amy Gutmann, a respected democracy scholar, her role as President Biden’s envoy to Germany is not a job. "It’s a mission," she said. https://t.co/JAGgd6Ykdc https://t.co/X4YflIbKOe
A slow-burning hostility to constitutional abortion rights runs through the career of Justice Samuel Alito, the author of the Supreme Court opinion overturning Roe v. Wade. https://t.co/pjJEdEVXfN

After signing into law the bipartisan gun bill at the White House on Saturday morning, President Biden was asked by a reporter if he thought the Supreme Court was broken.
"I think the Supreme Court has made some terrible decisions," he said. https://t.co/MuTJBcHE7i https://t.co/NtqilLWmyv

In her latest letter to Democratic lawmakers about the decision to end Roe v. Wade, Speaker Nancy Pelosi said the Supreme Court was "guilty of a miscarriage of justice." https://t.co/sLRt2YJ76A https://t.co/vimEO7cVXL

The Broadway farce "POTUS" features a moment in which a character blurts out that she volunteers at an abortion clinic in Iowa. On Friday night, her line saying that "affordable, safe reproductive health care is a basic human right" stopped the show. https://t.co/JXmiMj57FO https://t.co/q9Hf5hz4BN

The list of companies that have said they will cover travel expenses for employees in need of abortions continues to grow, including H&M, Bank of America and Intuit. Google said employees could apply to relocate "without justification." https://t.co/ZnP6Frej7o

During a two-hour meeting in 2018, Senator Susan Collins of Maine pressed Brett Kavanaugh on why she should trust him not to overturn Roe v. Wade.
Meeting notes show Kavanaugh worked vigorously to reassure her that he was no threat to the landmark ruling. https://t.co/1jUW6ypGVT

Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida signed a law in April banning abortions after 15 weeks of pregnancy, severely curtailing access to the procedure. On Friday, he praised the Supreme Court’s decision, saying "the prayers of millions have been answered." https://t.co/RmlIFg9H8z

In Arizona, police deployed tear gas and state senators called a recess late Friday after abortion rights protesters amassed outside the State Capitol, with some banging on the glass. https://t.co/AC0oyvYspk

Meta, which owns Facebook and Instagram, told its workers not to openly discuss the Supreme Court’s ruling overturning Roe v. Wade on wide-reaching communication channels inside the company. https://t.co/LIisUqyHKX

A shooting near a popular gay club in downtown Oslo that killed two people and seriously wounded at least 10 is being investigated as an act of terrorism, as Norwegians grappled with a rare gun attack that shattered an expected Pride weekend celebration. https://t.co/N8IRrL8abx

All six Supreme Court justices in the majority opinion striking down Roe v. Wade avoided directly stating in their confirmation hearings how they would rule on it. They typically stuck to expressing their belief in the importance of precedent. https://t.co/7n2bQRyKKL https://t.co/VTaE7XJPPj
This was the New York Times front page on the day in 1973 that the Supreme Court decided Roe v. Wade in a 7-2 vote. https://t.co/EZMsBqhCtq
